You can google eating disorder clinics in your area. They usually offer free diagnosis and consultations. You can inquire about it when you call. Based on your habits, etc. theyâ€™ll recommend a level of care for you. Youâ€™re not obligated to accept treatment of any form from them, but you can ask for referrals to specialists in your area. This could get you linked up with a therapist that can help you work through some of your food issues. You could also ask them for other available resources!

Iâ€™ve /heard/ that weight distribution can definitely do this. Your body is going to want to redeposit fat where itâ€™s most necessary (around vital organs) before it goes anywhere else. I read about this on some recovery website that noted the initial gain as a potential trigger for people trying to recover from eating disorders. They said that the tummy gains are temporary and fat will begin to deposit more evenly with continued weight gain. It could also be bloat. I ate like shit for 5 days while on vacation and got a noticeable pudge in just my stomach that subsided after I got back on my bullshit.

You can bake! I quit for a long time. But I recently started up again, and it can be kind of fun, even if you have a lot of restrictions. Sure, thereâ€™s some recipes I wonâ€™t touch. Thereâ€™s just too many fear foods in them, and I can only substitute so much without destroying an entire recipe. But Iâ€™ve found quite a few recipes that I can manipulate enough to be comfortable for me, and itâ€™s also helped me work through some of my fear foods. Iâ€™ll really want to make a recipe, and the grocery list seems terrifying and daunting.. so Iâ€™ll choose one fear food ingredient to remain on the list, usually the one that I know I canâ€™t find a work around for. And then Iâ€™m relatively surprised that it doesnâ€™t actually contribute as negatively to the nutrition of the finished product, as my lizard brain wanted me to believe. I also just feel like baking is one of the only times where Iâ€™m actually /not/ focusing so much on my disorder. Iâ€™m just working on the task at hand and creating something really awesome. I like to work with recipes that freeze well, in case I wonâ€™t finish them, or things that my friends and family might enjoy if I need to get rid of some stuff. I think you should go for it. Even if you just bake for someone else. When you enjoy baking and cooking, it can be really therapeutic. I think you should give it another go.

Tbh, the accountability helps. My team is really understanding if I fuck up.. and thatâ€™s an important aspect of working through a reliance, and also something you should consider with choosing an accountability buddy. You donâ€™t want to feel guilty if you mess up, but you do want someone to be able to be like, itâ€™s okay.. just try again. I started taking it again after my first streak because I just hit a wall. I literally got sent home from work because my coworkers were like ...dude.. you look like shit.. go home and sleep. And then I called out the next day because getting out of bed was just awful. I hate that when I first take a dose Iâ€™m like.. on top of everything... but by the end of the day Iâ€™m sweating, and jittery.. and just feel terrible. It doesnâ€™t even make sense to do it from a weight loss perspective, because it really doesnâ€™t aid me in that anymore. Iâ€™ve hit a pretty low weight and I just donâ€™t lose as fast regardless of popping pills, etc. As for appetite suppression, it works, but sometimes Iâ€™ll eat anyway just to try and ease my shakiness. And it doesnâ€™t matter how much water I drink.. the dehydration from those stupid pills gives me the worst Charlie horses. Iâ€™m doing a lot better this week, if that gives you any hope. I still get tired sometimes, but I just try and remind myself that the alternative is a quick boost and then Iâ€™m going to feel just as awful. I try and just drink a green tea or a coffee and power through it.

Calorie count also includes the erythritol brown sugar, pecan chips, and cream cheese frosting on top. The frosting is just 1/2 tablespoon of Daiya cream cheese, swerve confectioners sugar (erythritol), a dash of vanilla extract, and a sprinkle of cinnamon. For the baked oatmeal, set oven to 375Â°F, you will bake the oatmeal for 15-20 minutes in a 10oz ramekin, then broil on high for 2-3 minutes.  This recipe is a slightly modified Chocolate Covered Katie recipe. 1/2 cup of rolled oats, 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract, 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon or more to taste, (CCK posts use 1 1/2 tablespoons of liquid sweetener of choice, such as pure maple syrup), I used 2 tablespoons of sugar free pancake syrup and a pinch of stevia, 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, dash of salt, 1 tablespoon PBfit. Mix together, pour into a ramekin sprayed with cooking spray and bake!

Edit: I forgot to add 1/4 cup of unsweetened vanilla almond milk to the recipe above. Donâ€™t forget that part lol.

I work in a healthcare setting, and thereâ€™s something we call empathy fatigue. It sounds like as a parent, sheâ€™s gone through a lot regarding your disorder. I donâ€™t think that she doesnâ€™t care. I think sheâ€™s probably just worn out. My boyfriend has a tendency to get worn out as well. You mentioned having recovery friends and support groups, so for the time being it might be better for you, as well as her, if you share your thoughts/secrets/struggles with them, and let your mom recoup. After some time away from your disorder, she may ask you how itâ€™s going on her own terms.

When I went home to visit my family, I had just told them about being diagnosed with an ED. My step dad was already speculating based on instagram pictures so I just confirmed it ahead of time to avoid being grilled when I got there. So of course as soon as I walk through the door, Iâ€™m greeted by disapproving and concerned looks from my step father, and then my mom chimes in that Iâ€™m not /that/ skinny, and the recovery center is probably just using me as an easy insurance claim lol. Iâ€™m not underweight, but Iâ€™m close to it, and even now after hashing it out with my mom about how minimizing my disorder is NOT helpful, she still maintains that x amount of pounds over the underweight category is totally fine, and I probably donâ€™t need as intensive therapy as recommended. But let me tell you, it was suuuuuuuper awkward just standing there for about an eternity with both of my parents studying my body, making comments about my weight, and even arguing with each other about it. I think people who arenâ€™t stuck in an ED mindset, donâ€™t really see how much of an impact their comments can make. Weâ€™re getting to a place in society where thereâ€™s more bOdY pOsItIvItY, and women are striving to be â€œthicc AFâ€...  So even though your mind immediately takes those kinds of comments and runs with them, most people probably donâ€™t mean it in a negative way, or mean for it to be perceived in a negative way. Itâ€™s still inconsiderate AF though.

Sure, just as a little extra motivation, Iâ€™m not sure what you have to be â€œreadyâ€ for.  No one in OP makes you /do/ anything. Theyâ€™re just there to talk things out with you and offer support. As of right now Iâ€™m doing OP. I would highly recommend them, and they do offer OP for relapse. I would suggest setting up an assessment with them, because there is a bit of a waiting list for OP. It took about a month between my assessment and them being able to set me up with a psych. Thanks for this! :]

So yeah, Iâ€™m PHP level and they have me in OP right now because of barriers. Same thing. Having trouble with needing PHP but being self reliant, so a lot of it is game planning how I can get into PHP because when it comes down to it, that would benefit me the most. I need more support than OP offers. Theyâ€™re still working on my ED, but also being really helpful and trying to help me with insurance, looking at grants, looking for an outside clinic ED therapist for added support if my 90 day OP program ends before Iâ€™m able to get into PHP. 
Definitely give it another try! If youâ€™re lucky enough to live in a big city like I do, with multiple clinics, try a different clinic. My care team takes on the approach of yeah, I need higher care, like NEED it, but what can they do in the meantime to give me PHP level care and support with the time they have working with me, and get me on track to being more stable to try getting into PHP with everything else I have on my plate, or find the next best option. Recovery shouldnâ€™t just be an option for those with perfect life circumstances, and I really hope you find a team that realizes that, this time around! 
Also, just going to warn that a lot of RDs wonâ€™t work with someone needing a high level of care if you donâ€™t already have a psych working with you, because they wonâ€™t, in good consciousness, take your money if they donâ€™t think itâ€™ll be beneficial for you. Start with a specialized psych, even if itâ€™s not through a program, you can get a referral list of ED therapists through a recovery center. I would start there! :]

2. Gradually reintroduce fear foods.

4. Be a better caretaker to my body.

I had this problem. Honestly I just knew that I had enough. I was letting a number dictate how my day was going to go. Or what kind of mood I was going to be in. For me, it came down to pure motivation. Acknowledging that weighing myself so frequently was literally the most detrimental think I was doing to my emotional/mental well being, and wanting to correct that behavior. I honestly just started challenging myself to leave it alone. At first the most I went was a whole day. Then it became 3 day. Etc, etc. now I can go about a week if I need to. If I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m going to like the number, I donâ€™t torture myself by looking at it. It took me a few months to get to that point. But itâ€™s really just a matter of recognizing the impulse, and deciding to try and go against it.

First. Remember that most of those kgs are from water retention, so donâ€™t freak out. As a rule of thumb, I avoid the scale for at least a week if Iâ€™m worried Iâ€™m going to see a lot of water weight in the number. Second. Donâ€™t over compensate and get extra restricty on yourself. Drink lots of water. Last time I had a lot of retention from eating stuff I donâ€™t normally eat while on vacation, and I was feeling extra bloaty, someone suggested dandelion tea. It seemed to help a lot. The most important thing is to just get hydrated, donâ€™t punish yourself, and definitely donâ€™t beat yourself up over it.

Iâ€™m vegan, so all of my recipes are of that variety. However. Cookies are especially hard to keep the calorie count down because they use a lot of butter. I find thatâ€™s where all the calories come from, even when using sugar replacement like swerve. If you are just dyyying for cookies, and thatâ€™s what you want/need. I suggest just making a normal recipe, and cutting down part of the calories using swerve sugar replacement. You can find it at most Whole Foods stores, or check the website for the store locator. Call ahead though, because I found that it can be misleading. They have 0 cal brown sugar which will be relatively handy for cookie baking. Honestly though, Iâ€™ve found the easiest way to get a dessert fix while keeping it low cal is just making a mug cake with the replacements. Under 200 calories for a decent sized treat. Otherwise, youâ€™re just going to have to tweak a recipe and still focus heavily on portion control.

I need to be able to be comfortable with the skills before submerging myself in harder tasks. And I beg to differ that itâ€™s like drug addiction. Probably useless advice because I know how hard it is to put action behind the words, but damn bby, take the care. â˜¹ï¸ Do what you need to do to get better. It probably momentarily felt good to get the b/p out of your system, but now look at where it got you. It didnâ€™t make you feel happy or fulfilled, right? It just satisfied a temporary urge, but made you feel worse in the long run. So recovery is probably going to be the opposite of that. Itâ€™s going to be really hard, and really uncomfortable.. but you have a shot at being better if you just go through the motions and try to get through it. If youâ€™re having really strong urges, talk them out with your care team. Tell them what youâ€™re going through and why. Maybe if they understand, theyâ€™ll be able to help you get through it and stay accountable. Iâ€™m not recovered, but Iâ€™m working with a team currently. I definitely want to run for the hills just thinking about whatâ€™s expected of me, and goals that I have to meet. But Iâ€™m actively trying to push past some of that discomfort and set up a safety bet of a few trusted individuals who can help urge me forward when I want to turn the other way and run. I wish you the best of luck, and I really hope that when shit gets tough, you get tougher. ğŸ’œ
